Award.AwardTitle: Fire, Land Use and the Savannazation of Seasonally-dry Amazon Forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
Each year, about one fifth of all of the carbon dioxide that is emitted to the atmosphere through human activities around the world comes from the clearing and burning of moist tropical forests. During years of severe drought, large areas of forest catch fire, doubling these emissions. Once burned, forests are more likely to burn again in a vicious cycle of forest degradation that further increases carbon emissions to the atmosphere as it damages rainforests. This research will shed light on the processes that determine the response of forests to fire, and the likelihood of large-scale "savannization" of the Amazon - the transformation of rainforest into fire-prone brush vegetation. It will achieve this through field experiments and measurements of burned forests that determine the effects of Amazon forest fire on subsequent invasion by flammable weeds and tree death - two factors that strongly influence the risk of further burning. The data obtained will be used to modify a vegetation model of the Amazon that will be used to predict the likelihood of large-scale savannization and its potential contribution of carbon to the atmosphere. Currently, models that predict the future of tropical forests in a warming world do not include fire, weed invasion, and land use.

This research will fill an important gap in knowledge of how tropical forests in the Amazon will respond to climate change and growing economic pressures on tropical forests. This project also will support international education student exchanges and public-outreach activities aimed at environmental literacy.

Fire, Land Use, and the Savannization of Seasonally-dry Amazon Forests.

Intellectual merits:

Future interactions between a changing climate and agricultural expansion may drive widespread degradation of Amazonian forests. High-intensity fires associated with extreme drought events could accelerate this degradation by abruptly increasing tree mortality, but this process remains poorly understood. In this 5-year NSF funded project two 50-hectare forest plots in southeast Amazonia were repeatedly burned to investigate how fire frequency and weather conditions affected tree mortality and vegetation regrowth (Figures 1-4). The fire experiment provided important insights into the effects of fire on tropical forest dynamics. The findings showed that tree mortality from fire is strongly affected by plant characteristics and climate. Trees with thicker bark were better able to survive repeated fires. However, climate also played a major role. Abrupt increases in fire-induced tree mortality occurred during a severe drought event. This threshold mortality response had a cascading effect, causing sharp declines in canopy cover and allowing widespread invasion by flammable grasses across the forest edge (Figure 5). These outcomes show that a few extreme drought events, coupled with forest fragmentation and anthropogenic ignition sources, are already causing widespread fire-induced tree mortality and forest degradation across southeastern Amazon forests. Future projections of vegetation responses to climate change across drier portions of the Amazon require more than simulation of global climate forcing alone, they must also include interactions of extreme weather events, fire, and land-use change.

Broader impacts:

This project has resulted in numerous broader impacts related to education, outreach, and research facilities. 

It has contributed to the training of three US graduate students, one US Hispanic graduate student and post-doctoral fellow, two post-doctoral fellows in the US (one Brazilian citizen, one US citizen), three Brazilian graduate students at US universities and seven Brazilian graduate students at Brazil universities. Collaborations among the principal investigators have led to several other interdisciplinary projects funded by NSF, NASA, CNPq, and the Belmont Forum, which are supporting numerous students and researchers in the US and Brazil.

Tanguro Ranch where the fire experiments were performed has become the site of important collaborations among US, Brazilian, and European researchers and educational institutions, important non-governmental policy and research organizations (the Institute for Amazon Environmental Research-IPAM and Aliança da Terra-AT) and a large Brazilian soybean producing and trading company (Grupo Andre Maggi). This site now plays a disproportionately important role in scientific investigation of the ecology of the Amazon and tropical agricultural in general in the face of changing land use and climate.

Results of this project summarizing how fires of human origin affect forest health have been presented to many diverse groups. These outcomes have been presented to Grupo Maggi (the corporate owners of Tanguro ranch) managers and have informed management decisions. Findings have been presented to municipal and state environmental regulatory agencies, indigenous peoples leadership groups, agricultural growers and rancher’s organizations, along with middle and high schools in Mato Grosso.
